synonymGroups.title: Words for Love
synonymGroups.introduction: English has only one primary word for 'love,' but Greek distinguishes between different types and expressions of love. Understanding these distinctions illuminates Jesus' famous exchange with Peter in John 21 and reveals the depth of God's love throughout Scripture.

words.nuance: The distinctively Christian word for love. It denotes a deliberate, reasoned, purposeful love that seeks the highest good of the beloved regardless of their merit or response. This is the love of choice and will, not merely emotion.

Denotes tender affection, the love of friendship and natural emotional attachment. It implies warmth, fondness, and personal delight in the one loved. Often used for family affection and close friendship.
Natural family affection, especially between parents and children. Appears only in compounds in the NT (ἄστοργος, φιλόστοργος), emphasizing natural bonds of kinship.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Agapaō is distinguished from phileō in this, that the former more frequently involves the idea of showing love by action, the latter more frequently suggests the idea of cherishing, of having affection for.

exampleVerse.greek: Σίμων Ἰωάννου, ἀγαπᾷς με πλέον τούτων;... φιλῶ σε
exampleVerse.english: Simon son of John, do you love (agapaō) me more than these?... I love (phileō) you.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When you see 'love' in your English Bible, ask: Is this ἀγαπάω (deliberate, sacrificial choice) or φιλέω (warm affection)? The distinction often reveals whether the emphasis is on commitment or emotion.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Know
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between knowledge gained through experience or learning and knowledge that is intuitive or complete. This distinction appears throughout the NT and affects our understanding of how we come to know God and truth.

words.nuance: Denotes knowledge acquired through experience, observation, or learning. It suggests a progressive, growing knowledge that develops over time. Used for coming to know something that was previously unknown.

Denotes fullness of knowledge, absolute or intuitive knowledge. It suggests knowing something completely without needing to learn it progressively. Often used of divine knowledge or settled convictions.
Knowledge based on close acquaintance or expertise. Suggests understanding how something works or being skilled in something. The root of our word 'epistemology.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Ginōskō frequently suggests inception or progress in knowledge, while oida suggests fullness of knowledge.

exampleVerse.greek: καὶ οὐκ ἐγνώκατε αὐτόν, ἐγὼ δὲ οἶδα αὐτόν
exampleVerse.english: You do not know (ginōskō) him, but I know (oida) him.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: γινώσκω often appears for growing in knowledge of God (Phil 3:10 'that I may know him'), while οἶδα appears for settled certainties (1 John 5:13 'that you may know you have eternal life').

synonymGroups.title: Words for See
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has multiple words for seeing, each emphasizing a different aspect of perception. Some stress physical sight, others contemplation, and still others spiritual perception or revelation.

words.nuance: The most general word for seeing, emphasizing the physical act of seeing or looking. Often used for ordinary observation without implying deep understanding.

Denotes seeing with understanding or spiritual perception. Often used for supernatural visions, seeing the significance of something, or perceiving truth. The aorist εἶδον emphasizes the completed act of perception.
To view attentively, contemplate. Originally used for spectators at games or theater. Suggests careful observation and consideration of what is seen. Root of our word 'theory.'
To behold, view with a sense of wonder or appreciation. Emphasizes the impressive nature of what is seen. Often used for beholding Christ's glory.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Horaō and blepō both denote the physical sense of seeing; horaō, in general, implies direction of the thoughts to what is seen, while blepō denotes the act of seeing more specifically.

exampleVerse.greek: καὶ ἐθεασάμεθα τὴν δόξαν αὐτοῦ
exampleVerse.english: And we beheld (theaomai) his glory

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Scripture uses θεάομαι or θεωρέω instead of simple βλέπω, it's inviting you to contemplate and marvel, not just observe. Slow down and wonder.

synonymGroups.title: Words for New
synonymGroups.introduction: English uses 'new' for both something recently made and something of a different quality. Greek distinguishes between new in time (νέος) and new in quality or nature (καινός). This distinction is crucial for understanding the 'new covenant' and 'new creation.'

words.nuance: New in respect to time, recently made or come into existence. Young as opposed to old. Emphasizes recency rather than difference in kind. A νέος garment is a recently-made garment of the same type.

words.shortDef: new (in quality, of a different kind)
words.nuance: New in quality, nature, or character. Not merely recent but different from what existed before - fresh, unprecedented, superior. A καινός covenant is not just a recent covenant but one of a fundamentally different character.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Kainos denotes that which is unaccustomed or unused, not new in time, recent, but new as to form or quality, of different nature from what is contrasted as old.

exampleVerse.greek: εἴ τις ἐν Χριστῷ, καινὴ κτίσις
exampleVerse.english: If anyone is in Christ, he is a new (kainos) creation

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The 'new covenant' (καινή διαθήκη) is not just the most recent covenant but a covenant of an entirely different character. The 'new creation' is not just a refreshed version of the old but something qualitatively different.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Time
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between time as duration (χρόνος) and time as opportune moment (καιρός). This distinction reveals God's sovereign ordering of history and helps us understand biblical statements about 'times and seasons.'

words.nuance: Time in its extent or duration, the succession of moments. Measurable, quantitative time. The root of our word 'chronology.' Asks 'how long?' rather than 'what kind of time?'
The right, proper, or opportune time. A decisive moment, a season of unique significance. Qualitative rather than quantitative - emphasizing the character of the time rather than its length.
An age or era, a period of time with distinctive characteristics. Can refer to eternity when used of God's time. The biblical view of history as divided into 'this age' and 'the age to come.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Chronos marks quantity, kairos marks quality. Chronos is time measured; kairos is time as it affects circumstances or affords opportunities.

exampleVerse.greek: οὐχ ὑμῶν ἐστιν γνῶναι χρόνους ἢ καιροὺς
exampleVerse.english: It is not for you to know times (chronos) or seasons (kairos)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Scripture speaks of 'redeeming the time' (Eph 5:16), it uses καιρός - we are to make the most of opportune moments. Look for God-given opportunities, not just the passage of time.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Life
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between physical/biological life (βίος) and the principle of life itself, especially spiritual life (ζωή). John's Gospel especially uses ζωή for the divine life that Christ gives.

words.nuance: The period or manner of earthly life, the means of living (livelihood), or life in its outward manifestation. Concerns how we live in the world. Root of our word 'biology.'

words.shortDef: life (the principle of life, spiritual life)
words.nuance: Life in its fullest, highest sense. The vital principle, especially the divine life that belongs to God and is given through Christ. In John's writings, almost always refers to eternal, spiritual life.
The soul, the seat of personality, desires, and emotions. Can refer to physical life that can be lost (Matt 16:25) or the inner person. Root of our word 'psychology.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Zōē is used of life as a principle, life in the absolute sense, life as God has it. Bios is used of the period or duration of life.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ὁδὸς καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια καὶ ἡ ζωή
exampleVerse.english: I am the way, the truth, and the life (zōē)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When John speaks of 'eternal life' (ζωὴ αἰώνιος), he means not just life that lasts forever but a quality of life - God's own life shared with us. It's not just duration but divine nature.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Word
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has multiple terms for 'word,' each with distinct emphases. The most famous is λόγος, used for Christ in John 1, but ῥῆμα also appears frequently with its own nuances.

words.nuance: A word as the expression of thought, not the mere name of an object. Can mean word, speech, account, reason, or the divine Word (Christ). Emphasizes the underlying thought or meaning expressed.

A word as spoken, a specific saying or utterance. Emphasizes the word as actually communicated, the spoken expression rather than the underlying concept. Often used for specific divine commands or promises.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: The distinction between logos and rhēma is that the former denotes the expression of thought, the latter a saying or statement. In regard to the Scriptures, logos is the expression of divine thought as a whole; rhēma denotes particular words or sayings.

exampleVerse.greek: ἄρα ἡ πίστις ἐξ ἀκοῆς, ἡ δὲ ἀκοὴ διὰ ῥήματος Χριστοῦ
exampleVerse.english: So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word (rhēma) of Christ

synonymGroups.practicalTip: λόγος emphasizes Scripture as God's complete revelation and thought; ῥῆμα emphasizes specific words God speaks to us. Both are essential - the whole counsel of God and His specific direction.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Temple
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between the entire temple complex (ἱερόν) and the inner sanctuary where God's presence dwelt (ναός). This distinction illuminates many NT passages about worship, Jesus' body, and the church.

words.nuance: The whole temple complex including courts, porticos, and surrounding areas. Where the people gathered, commerce occurred, and daily activities took place. Anyone could enter certain areas.
The inner shrine, the sanctuary proper where God's presence dwelt. Only priests could enter the Holy Place, only the high priest the Holy of Holies. Used figuratively for believers as God's dwelling.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Hieron denotes the entire precincts of the Temple in its enlarged form, while naos is used of the inner sanctuary, the shrine itself.

exampleVerse.greek: τὸ σῶμα ὑμῶν ναὸς τοῦ ἐν ὑμῖν Ἁγίου Πνεύματός ἐστιν
exampleVerse.english: Your body is a temple (naos) of the Holy Spirit within you

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul says believers are God's ναός, he's not saying we're part of a religious complex - we are the very dwelling place of God's presence, as intimate and sacred as the Holy of Holies.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Another
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between another of the same kind (ἄλλος) and another of a different kind (ἕτερος). This distinction is crucial in passages about the Holy Spirit, false gospels, and Christ's uniqueness.

words.nuance: Another of the same sort, numerically distinct but qualitatively similar. When Jesus promises 'another Advocate' (ἄλλον παράκλητον), He means one of the same divine nature as Himself.
Another of a different quality or nature. Implies distinction not just in number but in kind. A 'different gospel' (ἕτερον εὐαγγέλιον) is fundamentally different from the true gospel.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Allos expresses a numerical difference and denotes another of the same sort; heteros expresses a qualitative difference and denotes another of a different sort.

exampleVerse.greek: ἄλλον Παράκλητον δώσει ὑμῖν
exampleVerse.english: He will give you another (allos) Helper

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Jesus calls the Spirit 'another Helper' (ἄλλος) - same divine nature, same advocacy, same comfort. But Paul warns against 'another gospel' (ἕτερος in Gal 1:6) - fundamentally different and therefore damning.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Sin
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has multiple words for human transgression, each highlighting a different aspect of sin. Together they give a comprehensive picture of humanity's fallen condition and need for redemption.

words.nuance: The most common NT word for sin. Originally an archery term meaning to miss the mark or target. Emphasizes falling short of God's standard, failure to be what God intended.
Transgression, overstepping a boundary. Implies a known law or command that has been deliberately crossed. Emphasizes willful disobedience to a clear standard.
A fall, slip, or false step. Suggests deviation from the right path, whether through carelessness or weakness. Less deliberate than parabasis but still culpable.
Lawlessness, disregard for law. Emphasizes the spirit of rebellion against God's authority, not just individual acts but a fundamental rejection of divine order.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Hamartia indicates a missing of the mark, the failure to attain to a fixed standard. Anomia indicates lawlessness, the disregard of law. Parabasis indicates the breaking of a definite law.

exampleVerse.greek: πάντες γὰρ ἥμαρτον καὶ ὑστεροῦνται τῆς δόξης τοῦ θεοῦ
exampleVerse.english: For all have sinned (hamartanō) and fall short of the glory of God

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The variety of Greek words for sin shows that our problem is comprehensive - we miss God's mark, cross His boundaries, slip from His path, and rebel against His authority. We need a comprehensive Savior.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Power
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between inherent power or ability (δύναμις) and delegated authority or right (ἐξουσία). Both are used of God and given to believers, but in different senses.

words.nuance: Inherent power, ability, or might. The capacity to do something, often miraculous. Root of 'dynamite' and 'dynamic.' Emphasizes power as force or energy.
Authority, the right or permission to act. Delegated power, jurisdiction, or liberty to do something. Emphasizes power as rightful authority rather than raw force.
Strength, might, especially as manifested. Often used of physical strength or the capacity for forceful action.
Dominion, ruling power, sovereignty. The power to control or govern. Often used in doxologies for God's supreme rule.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Dynamis is power in the sense of inherent ability or capability; exousia is authority, the right to exercise power.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐν ἐξουσίᾳ καὶ δυνάμει ἐπιτάσσει τοῖς ἀκαθάρτοις πνεύμασιν
exampleVerse.english: With authority (exousia) and power (dynamis) he commands the unclean spirits

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Jesus gave believers ἐξουσία (authority/right) to become children of God (John 1:12) and δύναμις (power/ability) through the Spirit (Acts 1:8). We have both the right and the resources.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Servant
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for those who serve, each emphasizing different aspects of service. Understanding these distinctions clarifies roles in the church and the nature of Christian service.

words.nuance: A slave, one bound to a master. Emphasizes complete ownership and absolute submission. Paul's favorite term for his relationship to Christ - total devotion with no rights of his own.
A servant or attendant, one who renders service to another. Less emphasis on bondage, more on active ministry. Root of 'deacon.' Used for table service and general ministry.
An under-rower, then any subordinate acting under another's direction. Suggests willing assistance and cooperation. Used for synagogue attendants and officers of various kinds.
A servant, but with dignity - a personal attendant. Used only of Moses in the NT (Heb 3:5), suggesting honored service. Root of 'therapist.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Doulos denotes one who is in permanent relation of servitude to another, his will being wholly subject to the will of the other. Diakonos suggests more the idea of service than subjection.

exampleVerse.greek: Παῦλος δοῦλος Χριστοῦ Ἰησοῦ
exampleVerse.english: Paul, a servant (doulos) of Christ Jesus

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Paul calls himself Christ's δοῦλος (slave) - he belongs entirely to Jesus. But to others he is a διάκονος (minister) - actively serving their needs. Total devotion upward, active service outward.

synonymGroups.title: Words for World
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek uses several words translated 'world,' each with distinct meanings. Understanding these distinctions clarifies passages about Christian engagement with culture and eschatological hope.

words.nuance: The ordered world, the universe, or humanity as a whole. Can be neutral (God so loved the world) or negative (the world's system opposed to God). Emphasizes order and arrangement.
An age, a period characterized by certain features. 'This age' vs 'the age to come.' When translated 'world,' emphasizes the temporal, passing nature of the present order.
The inhabited world, the known world, the Roman Empire. Geographic rather than moral or temporal. Root of 'ecumenical.'
The earth as opposed to heaven, or a particular land/region. Physical ground, territory. Can mean the whole earth or a specific country.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Kosmos is used of the earth as distinct from the universe, of mankind, and of the world system opposed to God. Aiōn stresses the idea of a period of time, an era.

exampleVerse.greek: μὴ συσχηματίζεσθε τῷ αἰῶνι τούτῳ
exampleVerse.english: Do not be conformed to this world (aiōn)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul warns against conformity to 'this age' (αἰών), he emphasizes its temporary, passing nature. We live in this age but belong to the age to come. Don't invest too heavily in a passing order.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Ask
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between asking as a request or petition and asking as inquiry. It also differentiates based on the relationship between the one asking and the one asked.

words.nuance: To ask for something, to request or petition. Often implies asking from an inferior to a superior position. Used for prayer requests to God.

words.shortDef: to ask (inquire, or ask as equal)
words.nuance: To ask a question or inquire, or to make a request as one with a close relationship. Jesus uses this word for His intercession because He asks as the Son, not as a petitioner.
To beg or beseech, expressing an urgent need. More intense than aiteō, emphasizing the petitioner's felt need and earnestness.
To call to one's side, hence to appeal, urge, comfort, or encourage. Can be asking but with the nuance of coming alongside to support or persuade.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Aiteō suggests the attitude of a suppliant, the petition of one who is lesser. Erōtaō suggests the familiarity of equals, or the request of one who has a right to ask.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐν ἐκείνῃ τῇ ἡμέρᾳ ἐν τῷ ὀνόματί μου αἰτήσεσθε
exampleVerse.english: In that day you will ask (aiteō) in my name

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Jesus uses ἐρωτάω when He intercedes for us (John 17:9) - He asks as the beloved Son with intimate access. We use αἰτέω as petitioners, but through Christ we can 'ask in His name' with confidence.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Prayer
synonymGroups.introduction: The NT uses several words for prayer, each highlighting different aspects of communion with God. Together they give a rich vocabulary for our relationship with the Father.

words.nuance: The most general and comprehensive word for prayer. Includes adoration, confession, thanksgiving, and supplication. Exclusively used for prayer to God, never to humans.
To beg or entreat, emphasizing the petitioner's sense of need. More intense than a general request, it expresses urgency and dependency.
To ask for something specific, to petition. When used of prayer, emphasizes specific requests brought to God.
To meet with, hence to make intercession. Used for Christ's and the Spirit's intercession for believers. Suggests personal access and pleading on another's behalf.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Proseuchomai is used of prayer in general; deomai stresses the sense of need; aiteō emphasizes the request for particular things.

exampleVerse.greek: τὸ πνεῦμα ὑπερεντυγχάνει στεναγμοῖς ἀλαλήτοις
exampleVerse.english: The Spirit himself intercedes (hyperentynchanō) with groanings too deep for words

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When you don't know how to pray, remember that the Spirit ἐντυγχάνει (intercedes) for you - He has personal access to the Father and pleads on your behalf. Your weakness in prayer is covered.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Faith and Belief
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has related words for faith, belief, and trust that illuminate different aspects of saving faith. Understanding these distinctions enriches our grasp of how we relate to God through Christ.

words.nuance: Faith as a settled conviction, trust that rests on the character of another. Can mean the act of believing, the content of belief, or faithfulness/reliability. The primary NT word for saving faith.
The verb form - to believe, to entrust. With εἰς ('into') suggests committing oneself to Christ, not mere intellectual assent. Used 98 times in John's Gospel alone.
To persuade or win over, or (in perfect tense) to be persuaded, to have confidence. Emphasizes the process of becoming convinced rather than the state of faith.
Confidence, assurance, trust. The noun form of the perfect of πείθω. Emphasizes the settled state of trust that results from being convinced.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Pistis primarily means firm persuasion, a conviction based on hearing. It is used of faith in God or Christ, trust in the person and testimony of God.

exampleVerse.greek: Ἔστιν δὲ πίστις ἐλπιζομένων ὑπόστασις
exampleVerse.english: Now faith (pistis) is the substance of things hoped for

synonymGroups.practicalTip: πιστεύω εἰς Χριστόν (believe INTO Christ) suggests more than mental assent - it's committing your whole self to Him, like stepping onto a bridge you trust to hold you.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Grace and Mercy
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between unmerited favor (χάρις), compassion for the miserable (ἔλεος), and kindness in action (χρηστότης). These words together paint the full picture of God's gracious character.

words.nuance: Grace, unmerited favor, the free gift of salvation. Emphasizes the giver's generosity and the recipient's unworthiness. The distinctively Christian understanding goes beyond classical Greek usage.
Mercy, pity, compassion shown to those in distress or misery. Responds to human need and wretchedness. Often paired with grace - mercy for the miserable, grace for the guilty.
Kindness, goodness, benevolence. Grace and mercy expressed in tangible action. The practical outworking of a gracious disposition.
Pity, compassion, the inward feeling of mercy. Often used in the plural to emphasize the depths of divine compassion. More emotional than ἔλεος.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Grace and mercy are to be distinguished. Grace is shown to the guilty, mercy to the miserable. Grace meets our guilt, mercy meets our misery.

exampleVerse.greek: διὰ τὴν πολλὴν ἀγάπην αὐτοῦ ἣν ἠγάπησεν ἡμᾶς... χάριτί ἐστε σεσῳσμένοι
exampleVerse.english: Because of his great love... by grace (charis) you have been saved

synonymGroups.practicalTip: We need both χάρις and ἔλεος - grace because we are guilty before God, mercy because we are miserable in our sin. God provides both abundantly in Christ.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Forgiveness
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek uses different words for forgiveness, each emphasizing a different aspect - releasing a debt, graciously canceling, or the divine act of pardon. These distinctions enrich our understanding of God's forgiveness.

words.nuance: To send away, release, let go. When used for forgiveness, emphasizes dismissing the offense as if sending it away. The most common NT word for divine forgiveness.
To show grace, forgive freely, grant as a favor. Related to χάρις (grace). Emphasizes the gracious, undeserved nature of forgiveness. Used for forgiving debts and sins.
A passing by, pretermission. Used only in Rom 3:25 for God's temporary passing over of sins before Christ. Distinct from full forgiveness (ἄφεσις).
Release, pardon, forgiveness. The noun form of ἀφίημι. Complete remission of sins, not just passing over. Often in the phrase 'forgiveness of sins.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Aphiēmi literally means to send away. When applied to sins, it signifies letting them go, dismissing them as if they had never been. Charizomai adds the element of grace - forgiving freely and graciously.

exampleVerse.greek: χαρισάμενος ἡμῖν πάντα τὰ παραπτώματα
exampleVerse.english: Having forgiven (charizomai) us all our trespasses

synonymGroups.practicalTip: In Ephesians 4:32, we are to forgive (χαρίζομαι) 'as God in Christ forgave you' - freely, graciously, without demanding payment. This is costly forgiveness, not cheap tolerance.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Holy and Sacred
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words translated 'holy' or 'sacred,' each with distinct emphases. Understanding these helps us grasp both God's holiness and our calling to be holy.

words.nuance: Set apart for God, morally pure, sacred. The primary NT word for holiness. Emphasizes both separation from the profane and positive dedication to God. Used for God, believers, and sacred things.
Sacred, connected with religious rites and worship. Focuses on external, ceremonial holiness rather than moral purity. Root of 'hierarchy.' Rarely used in NT.
Holy in the sense of meeting divine requirements, devout, pious. Emphasizes conformity to God's will and character. Used of Christ and believers who fulfill their obligations to God.
To make holy, consecrate, sanctify. The verb form of ἅγιος. Can refer to initial sanctification (being set apart) or progressive sanctification (becoming more holy).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Hagios fundamentally signifies separated, and hence in Scripture is used of God, who is separated from all moral evil, and of persons and things separated to God.

exampleVerse.greek: ἅγιοι ἔσεσθε, ὅτι ἐγὼ ἅγιος
exampleVerse.english: Be holy (hagios), for I am holy (hagios)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: NT holiness (ἅγιος) is not merely ceremonial or external (ἱερός) but moral and personal. We are called to share in God's moral character, not just participate in religious rituals.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Righteous
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between righteousness in relation to law (δίκαιος) and piety in relation to God (ὅσιος). Both are essential aspects of Christian character.

words.nuance: Righteous, just, upright. Conforming to what is right by divine or human standards. The primary NT term for righteousness. Used both of legal standing before God and of actual conduct.
Righteousness, justice. The noun form. In Paul, often refers to the righteousness imputed by faith; in James and Matthew, often ethical righteousness in conduct.
Holy, devout, meeting one's obligations to God. While δίκαιος focuses on conformity to law, ὅσιος emphasizes inner devotion and piety.
To justify, declare righteous, acquit. The forensic term for God's declaration that sinners are righteous in Christ. The heart of Pauline soteriology.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Dikaios denotes right conduct toward men; hosios, piety toward God. The dikaios fulfills his duty to man; the hosios to God.

exampleVerse.greek: εἰς τὸ εἶναι αὐτὸν δίκαιον καὶ δικαιοῦντα τὸν ἐκ πίστεως Ἰησοῦ
exampleVerse.english: So that he might be just (dikaios) and the justifier (dikaioō) of the one who has faith in Jesus

synonymGroups.practicalTip: God is both δίκαιος (just, maintaining his righteous standard) and the one who δικαιόω (justifies) sinners. The cross satisfies both - justice is upheld, sinners are declared righteous.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Truth
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words related to truth, distinguishing between truth as reality, truthful speech, and genuine/authentic things. John especially develops the theological meaning of truth.

words.nuance: Truth as opposed to falsehood, reality as opposed to appearance. In John, truth is a theological concept connected to divine revelation and Christ himself. 'The truth shall set you free.'
True, truthful, honest. Describes a person who speaks truth or a statement that accords with reality. Emphasizes the correspondence with fact.

True in the sense of real, genuine, authentic. Not a copy or counterfeit but the original reality. Used of God as the true God, Christ as the true light, and the heavenly tabernacle as the true sanctuary.
Truly, really, indeed. The adverb form, confirming the reality or certainty of something. 'Truly this was the Son of God.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Alēthēs denotes true as opposed to false. Alēthinos denotes real, genuine, ideal, as opposed to what is fictitious, counterfeit, or merely typical.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ὁδὸς καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια καὶ ἡ ζωή
exampleVerse.english: I am the way, the truth (alētheia), and the life

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Christ is ἀλήθεια (truth/reality) and ἀληθινός (the genuine, authentic one). False christs are counterfeits; Jesus is the real thing. All truth ultimately connects to Him.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Wisdom
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between speculative wisdom (σοφία), practical wisdom (φρόνησις), and understanding (σύνεσις). These distinctions help us understand what Scripture means by true wisdom.

words.nuance: Wisdom, insight into the nature of things, especially the wisdom of God. In Paul, contrasted with worldly wisdom. Can refer to wisdom as a divine attribute or as a gift to believers.
Prudence, practical wisdom, the ability to discern the proper course of action. Wisdom applied to daily decisions and moral choices. Less philosophical than σοφία.
Understanding, intelligence, the ability to put things together mentally. From συν (together) + ἵημι (send). The capacity to comprehend relationships between ideas.
Knowledge, especially as acquired through learning or experience. In 1 Corinthians, sometimes used negatively of knowledge that puffs up without love. Distinguished from wisdom.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Sophia is insight into the true nature of things. Phronesis is the ability to discern modes of action with a view to their results. Synesis is understanding, the capacity to bring things together.

exampleVerse.greek: πληρωθῆτε τὴν ἐπίγνωσιν τοῦ θελήματος αὐτοῦ ἐν πάσῃ σοφίᾳ καὶ συνέσει πνευματικῇ
exampleVerse.english: Be filled with the knowledge of his will in all spiritual wisdom (sophia) and understanding (synesis)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: We need both σοφία (seeing truth) and φρόνησις (applying it wisely). Knowledge without practical wisdom leads to pride; practical wisdom without truth leads to pragmatism.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Fear
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between reverential awe (εὐλάβεια), fear that may be good or bad (φόβος), and cowardly fear (δειλία). The fear of the Lord is fundamentally different from sinful terror.

words.nuance: Fear, terror, or reverential awe. The most general word for fear. Can be negative (sinful fear) or positive (godly fear). Context determines whether it's healthy reverence or unhealthy terror.
Godly fear, reverence, pious caution. Always used positively for proper reverence toward God. From εὖ (well) + λαμβάνω (take) - handling sacred things with care.
Cowardice, timidity, fearfulness. Always used negatively in the NT. The opposite of the boldness believers should have. 'God has not given us a spirit of fear (δειλία).'
To fear, be afraid, or reverence. The verb form of φόβος. Used both for unhealthy fear ('fear not') and proper reverence for God ('fear God').

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Eulabeia is godly fear, the caution and carefulness that comes from a right view of God. Deilia is cowardice, a sinful fear that shrinks from difficulty or danger.

exampleVerse.greek: οὐ γὰρ ἔδωκεν ἡμῖν ὁ θεὸς πνεῦμα δειλίας
exampleVerse.english: For God gave us not a spirit of fear (deilia)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The 'fear of the Lord' (φόβος θεοῦ) is not δειλία (cowardice) but εὐλάβεια (reverence). It's the awe of a child before a loving Father, not the terror of a criminal before a judge.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Joy and Rejoicing
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for joy and gladness, ranging from quiet contentment to exuberant celebration. NT joy is distinctive - it persists through suffering and is rooted in relationship with God.

words.nuance: Joy, gladness, delight. The primary NT word for joy. Related to χάρις (grace). A deep-seated gladness that doesn't depend on circumstances. A fruit of the Spirit.
To rejoice, be glad, hail. The verb form of χαρά. Often used as a greeting ('Greetings!'). Commanded even in suffering - 'Rejoice in the Lord always.'
Exultation, exuberant joy, intense gladness. More demonstrative than χαρά. Often associated with worship and the presence of God. Root meaning suggests 'leaping for joy.'
Gladness, mirth, joyfulness. Often associated with feasting and celebration. The outward expression of a glad heart. From εὖ (well) + φρήν (mind).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Chara is joy in the deeper sense, more related to character. Agalliasis is exultation, the joyful expression of gladness. Euphrosynē is festive, merry joy.

exampleVerse.greek: ἀγαλλιᾶσθε χαρᾷ ἀνεκλαλήτῳ καὶ δεδοξασμένῃ
exampleVerse.english: You rejoice (agalliaō) with joy (chara) inexpressible and full of glory

synonymGroups.practicalTip: NT joy is not mere happiness (dependent on happenings) but χαρά rooted in God. Paul commands joy (Phil 4:4) - it's a choice rooted in relationship, not a feeling dependent on circumstances.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Peace
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between peace as harmony with God and others (εἰρήνη) and quietness of spirit or behavior (ἡσυχία). The Hebrew 'shalom' deeply influences the NT concept of peace.

words.nuance: Peace, harmony, tranquility. In the NT, infused with the OT concept of shalom - total well-being, not just absence of conflict. Peace with God through Christ; peace among believers.
Quietness, stillness, a quiet spirit. More about demeanor than relationship. The quiet confidence of trusting God rather than anxious striving.
To live at peace, be reconciled. The verb form calling believers to pursue harmony with others. 'If possible, so far as it depends on you, live peaceably with all.'
A peacemaker, one who makes peace. Used only in Matt 5:9, 'Blessed are the peacemakers.' Not passive peacekeeping but active reconciliation.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Eirēnē in the NT sense includes more than absence of war. It embraces all that makes for a person's highest good, reflecting the OT shalom.

exampleVerse.greek: δικαιωθέντες οὖν ἐκ πίστεως εἰρήνην ἔχομεν πρὸς τὸν θεόν
exampleVerse.english: Having been justified by faith, we have peace (eirēnē) with God

synonymGroups.practicalTip: εἰρήνη with God (Rom 5:1) is the foundation for the εἰρήνη of God (Phil 4:7). We must first be reconciled to God, then His peace guards our hearts.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Hope
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek ἐλπίς differs from English 'hope.' While we often use 'hope' for uncertain wishes, biblical hope is confident expectation based on God's promises. Other words add nuances of eager anticipation.

words.nuance: Hope, confident expectation. Not wishful thinking but assured anticipation based on God's character and promises. One of the three abiding virtues (faith, hope, love).
To hope, expect, trust. The verb form. Can be used with εἰς or ἐπί to show the object of hope. 'We have set our hope on the living God.'
To await eagerly, expect with stretched-out head. Compound word intensifying the idea of expectation. Used for waiting for Christ's return and the resurrection.
To expect, look forward to, wait for. Can be positive (expecting good) or negative (dreading evil). General expectation without the intensity of ἀπεκδέχομαι.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Elpis is not a mere wish but confident expectation. In the NT it is always directed toward God and the blessings He promises.

exampleVerse.greek: τῇ γὰρ ἐλπίδι ἐσώθημεν... δι᾽ ὑπομονῆς ἀπεκδεχόμεθα
exampleVerse.english: For in hope (elpis) we were saved... we wait eagerly (apekdechomai) for it with patience

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Biblical ἐλπίς is not 'I hope it doesn't rain' but 'I know God will keep His promises.' Our hope has a sure foundation - Christ's resurrection guarantees our future.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Anger and Wrath
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between settled indignation (ὀργή) and passionate outburst (θυμός). Both are attributed to God, yet without the sinful elements of human anger.

words.nuance: Wrath, anger, indignation. A settled disposition of righteous indignation rather than a sudden outburst. God's ὀργή is His consistent opposition to sin. Slow to develop but persistent.
Wrath, passion, hot anger. More sudden and explosive than ὀργή. Associated with boiling emotions. In humans, often sinful; in God, the consuming fire of judgment.
Indignation, vexation at something wrong. Righteous frustration at injustice or misunderstanding. The disciples' indignation at the anointing woman (Mark 14:4).
Provocation to anger, the state of being angered. Used in Eph 4:26 - 'do not let the sun go down on your parorgismos.' Anger that has been provoked.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Thumos indicates a more agitated condition of the feelings, an outburst of wrath from inward indignation. Orgē suggests a more settled or abiding condition of mind.

exampleVerse.greek: Ἀποκαλύπτεται γὰρ ὀργὴ θεοῦ ἀπ᾽ οὐρανοῦ
exampleVerse.english: For the wrath (orgē) of God is revealed from heaven

synonymGroups.practicalTip: God's ὀργή is not petty irritation but settled opposition to evil. We can be angry (ὀργίζεσθε) without sin (Eph 4:26) when our anger reflects God's holy opposition to injustice.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Send
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between sending with a commission (ἀποστέλλω) and simply dispatching someone (πέμπω). This distinction illuminates the nature of Jesus' mission and apostolic authority.

words.nuance: To send forth with a commission, dispatch with authority and purpose. The root of 'apostle.' Emphasizes the authority of the sender and the mission of the one sent.
To send, dispatch. More general than ἀποστέλλω, without the same emphasis on commission or authority. Often interchangeable but lacking the official, commissioned sense.
To cast out, thrust forth, send out. Stronger than simple sending - implies urgency or force. Used for casting out demons and for the Spirit 'driving' Jesus into the wilderness.
Intensified form of ἀποστέλλω - to send forth, send away. Often used for God sending the Spirit or sending prophets. Emphasizes the origin (from God) and purpose.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Apostellō stresses the commission, the relation of the one sent to the sender. Pempō stresses simply the sending, without the same emphasis on the nature of the mission.

exampleVerse.greek: καθὼς ἀπέσταλκέν με ὁ πατήρ, κἀγὼ πέμπω ὑμᾶς
exampleVerse.english: As the Father has sent (apostellō) me, even so I am sending (pempō) you

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Jesus was ἀπεσταλμένος - sent with full authority from the Father. An 'apostle' (ἀπόστολος) carries the sender's authority. We too are sent - with Christ's commission and authority.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Receive
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between taking/receiving actively (λαμβάνω) and welcoming/accepting (δέχομαι). A third word (παραλαμβάνω) emphasizes receiving something passed on. These nuances appear throughout the NT.

words.nuance: To take, receive, grasp. The most common word for receiving. Emphasizes the action of the recipient in taking hold of what is offered. Active reception.
To receive by way of welcome, accept deliberately and readily. Implies hospitality and positive response. Used for receiving guests, the gospel, and the kingdom.
To take to oneself, receive from another, take along. Often used for receiving tradition or teaching passed down. Paul 'received' (παρέλαβον) the gospel tradition.
To accept with approval, receive gladly. Intensified form of δέχομαι. Emphasizes the warmth and joy of reception. The Bereans 'received the word with all eagerness.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Dechomai suggests a favorable reception, a deliberate and ready acceptance. Lambanō is more neutral, simply indicating the act of receiving or taking.

exampleVerse.greek: παρέδωκα γὰρ ὑμῖν ἐν πρώτοις ὃ καὶ παρέλαβον
exampleVerse.english: For I delivered to you what I also received (paralambanō)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Paul παρέλαβεν (received as tradition) the gospel and παρέδωκεν (passed on) to others. We too are links in the chain - faithfully receiving and transmitting the apostolic faith.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Work and Do
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for working and doing, each with distinct nuances. Understanding these helps clarify passages about faith and works, and about Christian service.

words.nuance: To work, labor, perform work. Emphasizes labor and effort in accomplishing something. Related to ἔργον (work, deed). Used for working for wages and for spiritual labor.
To do, make, create. The most general word for doing. Emphasizes the product or result rather than the process. God 'made' (ἐποίησεν) heaven and earth.
To practice, do habitually, accomplish. More ethical than ποιέω - often used for practicing good or evil. Emphasizes the ongoing nature of the action.
To work out, accomplish, bring about. Intensified form of ἐργάζομαι. Suggests completing or achieving something. 'Work out your salvation' (Phil 2:12).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Poieō and prassō differ in that poieō implies a single act, while prassō suggests repeated or continuous practice. Prassō often has an ethical quality absent from poieō.

exampleVerse.greek: τὴν ἑαυτῶν σωτηρίαν κατεργάζεσθε... θεὸς γάρ ἐστιν ὁ ἐνεργῶν ἐν ὑμῖν
exampleVerse.english: Work out (katergazomai) your own salvation... for it is God who works (energeō) in you

synonymGroups.practicalTip: We κατεργάζομαι (work out) our salvation because God ἐνεργέω (works in) us. Divine sovereignty and human responsibility work together - we labor because He empowers.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Follow
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has different words for following - physical accompaniment, discipleship, and imitation. These distinctions illuminate what it means to follow Christ.

words.nuance: To follow, accompany as a disciple. The primary discipleship word. Originally meant following on the same road. Used for following Jesus physically and spiritually.
To imitate, follow as an example. Not mere external copying but deep emulation. Root of 'mimic.' Paul says 'imitate me as I imitate Christ.'
To follow closely, track. Intensified form of ἀκολουθέω. Used for following doctrine (1 Tim 4:6) and for sins following after judgment.
To follow together with, accompany. Compound with συν (together). Emphasizes companionship in following. The women 'followed with' Jesus from Galilee.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Akoloutheō is the characteristic word of discipleship in the Gospels. It signifies following as a disciple, with the thought of cleaving to the one followed.

exampleVerse.greek: δεῦτε ὀπίσω μου, καὶ ποιήσω ὑμᾶς γενέσθαι ἁλιεῖς ἀνθρώπων
exampleVerse.english: Follow (after) me, and I will make you fishers of men

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Discipleship is both ἀκολουθέω (following Jesus) and μιμέομαι (imitating Him). We walk where He walked and become like Him as we do. Following produces transformation.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Think and Consider
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has multiple words for thinking, each emphasizing different mental activities - calculating, setting the mind, reasoning, and supposing. Paul especially uses these to describe the transformed mind.

words.nuance: To reckon, calculate, consider as. Originally a commercial term for counting or calculating. Used for imputing righteousness and for deliberate mental consideration.

words.shortDef: to set the mind on (be minded)
words.nuance: To think, be minded, set the mind on. More than momentary thought - a settled disposition or mindset. 'Set your minds on things above.' The direction of one's thinking.
To suppose, assume, think according to custom. From νόμος (custom, law). Often introduces a supposition that may be mistaken. 'Do not think that I came to abolish the Law.'
To consider, regard, count. Often used for deliberate evaluation. Paul 'considers' all things loss compared to Christ. Root of 'hegemony' - leading thought.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Logizomai involves the bringing together of different reasons to make a decision. Phroneō implies the direction of the mind, the bent of the thoughts.

exampleVerse.greek: ὅσα ἐστὶν ἀληθῆ... ταῦτα λογίζεσθε
exampleVerse.english: Whatever is true... think (logizomai) about these things

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Paul commands us to λογίζομαι (deliberately calculate and consider) what is true, noble, right. We choose what occupies our minds. Transformed thinking is intentional, not accidental.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Judge
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between different kinds of judging - making distinctions, examining, condemning, and the final eschatological judgment. Understanding these clarifies when judgment is appropriate.

words.nuance: To judge, distinguish, decide. The basic word for judging. Can be neutral (making necessary distinctions), positive (judicial decision), or negative (condemning). Context determines the nuance.
To examine, investigate, question. Thorough investigation before judgment. The Bereans 'examined' the Scriptures. Used for judicial examination.
To separate, distinguish, discern. Making distinctions between things. Discerning spirits, discerning the body. Also used for doubting (being divided in mind).
To condemn, pass sentence against. Intensified form of κρίνω with κατά (against). Always negative - judging adversely. 'There is now no condemnation for those in Christ.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Krinō primarily denotes to distinguish, select, choose; hence to determine, to decide judicially. Katakrinō denotes to give judgment against, to condemn.

exampleVerse.greek: ὁ δὲ πνευματικὸς ἀνακρίνει μὲν πάντα
exampleVerse.english: The spiritual person examines (anakrinō) all things

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Not all 'judging' is forbidden. We must διακρίνω (discern) between truth and error, ἀνακρίνω (examine) teaching. What's forbidden is κατακρίνω (condemning) others hypocritically.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Hear and Listen
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between mere physical hearing (ἀκούω), obedient hearing (ὑπακούω), and answered prayer (εἰσακούω). True biblical 'hearing' involves response and obedience.

words.nuance: To hear, listen, understand. The basic word for hearing. Can be physical hearing or attentive listening. Root of 'acoustic.' 'He who has ears to hear, let him hear.'
To obey, hearken, answer the door. Compound: ὑπό (under) + ἀκούω (hear). Hearing that submits to what is heard. Obedience as the proper response to hearing God's word.
To hear with favor, answer prayer. Compound: εἰς (into) + ἀκούω (hear). God 'hearing' in the sense of granting the request. 'Your prayer has been heard.'
To hear carelessly, mishear, refuse to listen. Can mean overhearing accidentally or deliberately not heeding. 'If he refuses to listen (parakouō) to them, tell the church.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Akouo denotes hearing; the perception of sound. Hypakouo signifies to hearken submissively, to obey. The connection between hearing and obeying is fundamental in Scripture.

exampleVerse.greek: ἄρα ἡ πίστις ἐξ ἀκοῆς, ἡ δὲ ἀκοὴ διὰ ῥήματος Χριστοῦ
exampleVerse.english: So faith comes from hearing (akoē), and hearing through the word of Christ

synonymGroups.practicalTip: In Hebrew thought (influencing NT Greek), 'hearing' implies obedience. The Shema says 'Hear, O Israel' - meaning 'Listen and obey.' True hearing (ἀκούω) leads to obedience (ὑπακούω).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Speak and Say
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between speaking with emphasis on content (λέγω) and speaking with emphasis on the act of utterance (λαλέω). Other words add nuances of proclaiming and declaring.

words.nuance: To say, speak, tell. Emphasizes the content of what is said - the meaning, the message. Related to λόγος. 'Jesus said' typically uses λέγω when the content matters.
To speak, utter, talk. Emphasizes the act of speaking rather than the content. Often used for inspired utterance or ordinary conversation. 'He who speaks in a tongue.'
To affirm, assert, say. Often introduces direct speech, especially in replies. 'He said' in the sense of making an affirmation or reply. More formal than λέγω.
To speak forth, utter clearly and boldly. Used for inspired prophetic speech. The disciples at Pentecost 'spoke forth' as the Spirit gave utterance.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Lego affirms the purport of what is said; laleo marks the act of speaking. Lego is more for the matter, laleo for the manner of discourse.

exampleVerse.greek: ὁ πέμψας με πατὴρ αὐτός μοι ἐντολὴν δέδωκεν τί εἴπω καὶ τί λαλήσω
exampleVerse.english: The Father who sent me has given me a command - what to say (eipō) and how to speak (laleō)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: In John 12:49, Jesus distinguishes what to say (content) and how to speak (manner). Both matter in Christian witness - we need the right message delivered in the right way.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Save and Rescue
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for salvation and deliverance, each emphasizing different aspects - rescue from danger, redemption through payment, and preservation. Together they paint a full picture of what God has done for us.

words.nuance: To save, deliver, make whole, preserve. The primary NT word for salvation. Can refer to physical healing, rescue from danger, or spiritual salvation. Comprehensive deliverance.
To rescue, deliver, snatch from danger. Emphasizes the act of rescue from peril or evil. 'Deliver us from evil' uses this word. More dramatic than σῴζω.
To redeem, ransom, buy back. From λύτρον (ransom price). Emphasizes the payment made to secure release. Christ 'redeemed' us with His blood.
To set free, liberate. Emphasizes the resulting freedom rather than the means of deliverance. 'The truth shall set you free.' From bondage to liberty.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Sōzō is the comprehensive word for salvation in all its aspects. Rhyomai emphasizes deliverance from danger. Lytroō emphasizes the price paid for redemption.

exampleVerse.greek: ἔσωσεν ἡμᾶς... διὰ λουτροῦ παλιγγενεσίας
exampleVerse.english: He saved (sōzō) us... through the washing of regeneration

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Salvation is comprehensive: σῴζω (saved from sin's penalty and power), ῥύομαι (rescued from Satan's grip), λυτρόω (redeemed by Christ's blood), ἐλευθερόω (freed for new life).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Preach and Proclaim
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between herald-proclamation (κηρύσσω), gospel-announcement (εὐαγγελίζω), and teaching (διδάσκω). These represent different aspects of Christian ministry.

words.nuance: To herald, proclaim as a public crier. The herald (κῆρυξ) proclaimed the king's message with authority. Emphasizes the authoritative announcement of the message, not the messenger's own ideas.
To announce good news, preach the gospel. From εὖ (good) + ἄγγελος (messenger). Emphasizes the content as good news. Root of 'evangelize.'
To teach, instruct. More systematic than preaching - explaining, training, building understanding. Root of 'didactic.' Jesus 'taught' in synagogues.
To proclaim, announce publicly and thoroughly. Intensified form emphasizing complete and open proclamation. Paul 'proclaimed' Christ in the synagogues.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Kēryssō is to proclaim as a herald; it suggests formality, gravity, authority. Euangelizō is to announce glad tidings. Didaskō is to instruct in doctrine.

exampleVerse.greek: πῶς δὲ ἀκούσωσιν χωρὶς κηρύσσοντος;
exampleVerse.english: How are they to hear without someone preaching (kēryssō)?

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Effective ministry includes κηρύσσω (authoritative proclamation), εὐαγγελίζω (good news announcement), and διδάσκω (systematic teaching). Herald the truth, share the good news, build understanding.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Worship
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for worship, from prostrating before deity (προσκυνέω) to rendering religious service (λατρεύω) to reverential fear (σέβομαι). Each illuminates an aspect of true worship.

words.nuance: To worship, bow down, prostrate oneself. The most common NT word for worship. From πρός (toward) + κυνέω (kiss). Expressing homage and reverence, especially to deity.
To serve, render religious service or homage. Worship expressed through service. The whole of Christian life as worship-service. Root of 'liturgy.'
To revere, worship with devotion. Emphasizes the attitude of reverent awe. Often used for Gentile 'God-fearers' who worshiped the true God without full conversion.
To minister, perform public service. Originally civic duty, then priestly service. Root of 'liturgy.' Worship as public service rendered to God.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Proskyneō denotes an act of homage or reverence to God. Latreuō adds the thought of service. True worship involves both attitude (proskyneō) and action (latreuō).

exampleVerse.greek: πνεῦμα ὁ θεός, καὶ τοὺς προσκυνοῦντας αὐτὸν ἐν πνεύματι καὶ ἀληθείᾳ δεῖ προσκυνεῖν
exampleVerse.english: God is spirit, and those who worship (proskyneō) him must worship in spirit and truth

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Worship is both προσκυνέω (bowing in homage) and λατρεύω (serving in life). Sunday worship continues in Monday service. All of life is λατρεία - worship-service to God (Rom 12:1).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Repent
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between genuine repentance (μετανοέω) involving a complete change of mind and life, and mere regret (μεταμέλομαι). This distinction is crucial for understanding biblical conversion.

words.nuance: To repent, change one's mind and purpose. From μετά (change) + νοέω (think). A complete transformation of thought and direction. The repentance that leads to salvation.
Repentance, a change of mind. The noun form. Not mere emotion but a fundamental reorientation of thought, attitude, and life direction. 'Repentance unto life.'
To regret, feel remorse, have second thoughts. Different from μετανοέω - refers to the emotional response of regret without necessarily implying life change. Judas 'regretted' betraying Jesus.
To turn, turn around, convert. Often paired with μετανοέω - repent (change mind) and turn (change direction). Emphasizes the action of turning to God.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Metanoeo signifies to change one's mind or purpose, always in the NT involving a change for the better. Metamelomai signifies to regret, to experience an emotional change.

exampleVerse.greek: ἡ γὰρ κατὰ θεὸν λύπη μετάνοιαν εἰς σωτηρίαν ἀμεταμέλητον ἐργάζεται
exampleVerse.english: Godly sorrow produces repentance (metanoia) leading to salvation without regret (ametamelēton)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Judas μεταμέλομαι (regretted) but did not μετανοέω (repent). Peter wept bitterly and μετανοέω - his life changed. True repentance isn't just feeling sorry; it's a complete turnaround.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Body and Flesh
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between the body as an organized whole (σῶμα) and flesh as material substance (σάρξ). In Paul, σάρξ often has a theological sense of sinful human nature.

words.nuance: Body as an organized, living whole. Can refer to the physical body, the resurrection body, or metaphorically to the church as the 'body of Christ.' Generally neutral or positive.
Flesh, either literally (physical tissue) or theologically (the sinful nature). In Paul, often the principle of sin operating in unredeemed humanity. 'The flesh lusts against the Spirit.'
A member or part of the body. Used for body parts and for members of the church body. 'We are members one of another.'
A vessel, container, instrument. Metaphorically for the body as a container of the soul or as an instrument for use. 'We have this treasure in earthen vessels.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Sarx is the material of the body, soma is the body itself as an organized whole. In Paul, sarx often denotes mere human nature, especially in its weakness or sinfulness.

exampleVerse.greek: εἰ γὰρ κατὰ σάρκα ζῆτε, μέλλετε ἀποθνῄσκειν
exampleVerse.english: For if you live according to the flesh (sarx), you will die

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The body (σῶμα) is not evil - it will be resurrected. But the 'flesh' (σάρξ) as sinful nature must be put to death. We honor our bodies while crucifying our flesh.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Spirit and Soul
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between spirit (πνεῦμα) and soul (ψυχή). While related, they emphasize different aspects of the inner person. Understanding this illuminates NT anthropology.

words.nuance: Spirit, breath, wind. Can refer to the Holy Spirit, the human spirit, evil spirits, or the breath of life. The human spirit is the God-conscious aspect that relates to the divine.
Soul, life, self. The seat of feelings, desires, and personality. The life that can be lost (Matt 16:25) or the inner person. Root of 'psychology.'
Mind, intellect, understanding. The faculty of thinking and reasoning. The renewed mind transforms behavior (Rom 12:2). Can be darkened by sin or enlightened by the Spirit.
Heart, the center and seat of physical and spiritual life. Includes mind, will, and emotions. In Hebrew thought, the heart is the whole inner person, not just emotions.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Pneuma is that part of man which is related to God. Psyche is the seat of personality and natural life. The spirit is God-conscious, the soul is self-conscious.

exampleVerse.greek: ὁλόκληρον ὑμῶν τὸ πνεῦμα καὶ ἡ ψυχὴ καὶ τὸ σῶμα
exampleVerse.english: Your whole spirit (pneuma) and soul (psychē) and body (sōma)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: God renews our πνεῦμα (spirit - our connection to Him), transforms our νοῦς (mind - our thinking), heals our ψυχή (soul - our emotions), and will resurrect our σῶμα (body).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Remain and Abide
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for remaining and continuing. In John especially, 'abiding' (μένω) becomes a key concept for the believer's relationship with Christ.

words.nuance: To remain, stay, abide, dwell. The key Johannine word for the believer's union with Christ. Not temporary lodging but permanent residence. 'Abide in me, and I in you.'
To remain throughout, continue permanently. Intensified form of μένω. Emphasizes duration and persistence through time. 'Your years will never end.'
To stay on, persist, continue in. Remaining with purpose and determination. 'Shall we continue in sin?' The perseverance aspect of remaining.
To endure, remain under, persevere. Remaining steadfast under trial. From ὑπό (under) + μένω. 'He who endures to the end will be saved.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Meno denotes to remain, abide, whether in a place or in a state. It is the characteristic word in John for the mutual indwelling of the Father, Son, and believers.

exampleVerse.greek: μείνατε ἐν ἐμοί, κἀγὼ ἐν ὑμῖν
exampleVerse.english: Abide (menō) in me, and I in you

synonymGroups.practicalTip: John uses μένω 40 times! Salvation isn't just a moment but a permanent dwelling. We μένω (remain in Christ), διαμένω (continue consistently), ὑπομένω (endure through trials).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Destroy
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for destruction, from perishing eternally to demolishing structures. These distinctions clarify passages about eternal punishment and the temporary nature of created things.

words.nuance: To destroy, lose, perish. Can be active (destroy something) or middle (perish). Used for eternal destruction and for losing something valuable. 'Fear him who can destroy both soul and body.'
To dissolve, demolish, destroy by taking apart. Used for destroying the temple, abolishing law, or lodging (loosing one's pack). Breaking down structures.
To corrupt, destroy through corruption. Emphasizes the process of decay and ruin. Used for moral and physical corruption. 'Bad company corrupts good morals.'
Ruin, destruction, death. The noun for destruction. Not annihilation but ruination. 'Sudden destruction' comes upon those who say 'peace and safety.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Apollymi signifies to destroy utterly. The idea is not extinction but ruin, loss, not of being but of well-being. Eternal destruction is eternal ruin.

exampleVerse.greek: φοβεῖσθε τὸν δυνάμενον καὶ ψυχὴν καὶ σῶμα ἀπολέσαι ἐν γεέννῃ
exampleVerse.english: Fear him who can destroy (apollymi) both soul and body in hell

synonymGroups.practicalTip: ἀπόλλυμι doesn't mean annihilation but ruin. The 'lost' (ἀπολωλότα) sheep exists but is ruined. Hell is not ceasing to exist but eternal ruin - existing apart from all good.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Glory and Honor
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between divine glory/radiance (δόξα), honor/value (τιμή), and praise (αἶνος). These help us understand both God's nature and our calling to glorify Him.

words.nuance: Glory, splendor, radiance. God's glory is His manifested perfections. Can mean reputation, praise, or the visible manifestation of divine majesty. Root of 'doxology.'
Honor, value, respect. The recognition of worth. Also used for price (we were bought with a 'price'). 'Honor your father and mother.'
To glorify, honor, magnify. The verb form of δόξα. Used for glorifying God and for the Father glorifying the Son. Making known the glory that exists.
Praise, commendation. Specifically verbal expression of praise. Related to αἰνέω (to praise). 'Out of the mouth of infants you have perfected praise.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Doxa denotes the manifested excellence of God's character. The glory of God is what He is essentially. To glorify God is to acknowledge His glory.

exampleVerse.greek: δόξασόν με σύ, πάτερ, παρὰ σεαυτῷ τῇ δόξῃ ᾗ εἶχον πρὸ τοῦ τὸν κόσμον εἶναι παρὰ σοί
exampleVerse.english: Glorify (doxazō) me in your presence with the glory (doxa) I had with you before the world began

synonymGroups.practicalTip: We δοξάζω (glorify) God not by adding to His δόξα (glory) - that's impossible. We glorify Him by acknowledging, displaying, and praising the glory that already belongs to Him.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Appear and Manifest
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between shining forth (φαίνω), being made manifest (φανερόω), and a visible appearance (ἐπιφάνεια). These illuminate passages about Christ's incarnation and return.

words.nuance: To shine, give light, appear, become visible. Emphasizes the shining forth of what was hidden. The light 'shines' in the darkness. Root of 'phenomenon.'
To make manifest, reveal, make known what was hidden. More intentional than φαίνω - actively revealing something. Christ was 'manifested' to take away sins.
Appearing, manifestation, visible arrival. A technical term for Christ's visible appearances. Root of 'epiphany.' Used for both His first and second comings.
To uncover, reveal, disclose. From ἀπό (away) + καλύπτω (cover). Removing the veil to reveal what was hidden. Root of 'apocalypse.' Divine revelation.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Phaino is to shine, to become evident. Phaneroo is to make manifest, to make clear. Apokalypto is to uncover, to reveal what has been concealed.

exampleVerse.greek: οὔπω ἐφανερώθη τί ἐσόμεθα... ὅταν φανερωθῇ, ὅμοιοι αὐτῷ ἐσόμεθα
exampleVerse.english: What we will be has not yet been made manifest (phaneroō); when he appears (phaneroō), we shall be like him

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Christ's ἐπιφάνεια (appearing) will φανερόω (manifest) what we truly are. Our transformation isn't uncertain - it's simply not yet visible. When He appears, we appear with Him in glory.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Call
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between calling by name (καλέω), crying out (κράζω), and calling upon for help (ἐπικαλέω). These nuances illuminate God's calling of believers and our calling upon Him.

words.nuance: To call, name, invite, summon. God's effectual calling of believers to salvation. 'Called according to His purpose.' Also for naming ('His name shall be called Jesus').
To cry out, shout, scream. Strong vocal expression, often in distress or prayer. 'Abba, Father' cry of the Spirit. The blind man 'cried out' to Jesus.
To call upon, invoke, appeal to. Calling on a name for help or witness. 'Whoever calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.' Paul 'appealed' to Caesar.
To call to oneself, summon. Jesus 'calling' disciples to Himself. More personal than simple καλέω - inviting into relationship.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Kaleō is to call, to invite. Epikaleō is to call upon, to invoke for aid or witness. God's calling (klēsis) of believers is His effectual summons to salvation.

exampleVerse.greek: πᾶς γὰρ ὃς ἂν ἐπικαλέσηται τὸ ὄνομα κυρίου σωθήσεται
exampleVerse.english: Everyone who calls on (epikaleō) the name of the Lord will be saved

synonymGroups.practicalTip: God καλέω (calls) us to salvation; we ἐπικαλέω (call upon) His name for salvation. His call is effectual, enabling our response. We call because He first called.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Confess
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has different words for confession, from public acknowledgment (ὁμολογέω) to grateful confession (ἐξομολογέω). Both are essential to Christian faith and practice.

words.nuance: To confess, profess, acknowledge. From ὁμός (same) + λέγω (speak) - to say the same thing. Public profession of faith or acknowledgment of sin. 'If you confess with your mouth.'
To confess openly, acknowledge, praise. Intensified form with ἐκ. Often used for praise and thanksgiving, or for full confession of sins. 'Every tongue shall confess.'
Confession, profession. The noun form - our stated faith, our public declaration. 'Hold fast the confession of our hope.' The content of what we confess.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Homologeō signifies to speak the same thing, to agree, to confess. It involves the confession of facts, of faith, and of sins. Exomologeō adds the thought of open, full acknowledgment.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐὰν ὁμολογήσῃς ἐν τῷ στόματί σου κύριον Ἰησοῦν
exampleVerse.english: If you confess (homologeō) with your mouth that Jesus is Lord

synonymGroups.practicalTip: ὁμολογέω means to say the same thing as God - about our sin (agreeing it's wrong) and about Christ (agreeing He is Lord). Confession aligns our words with God's truth.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Sign and Miracle
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek uses different words for miraculous events, each emphasizing a different aspect - the significance (σημεῖον), the wonder (τέρας), or the power (δύναμις). John especially emphasizes signs that point to Christ.

words.nuance: A sign, token, indication. Emphasizes the meaning and significance of the miraculous event. John's Gospel calls Jesus' miracles 'signs' - they point to His identity and mission.
A wonder, marvel, portent. Emphasizes the astonishing nature of the event. Almost always paired with σημεῖον ('signs and wonders'). The emotional response of amazement.
Power, might, miracle. When used for miracles, emphasizes the power displayed. 'Mighty works' done by Jesus. The synoptic Gospels prefer this term.
Wonder, marvel, astonishment. The response of amazement to something extraordinary. 'No wonder' = θαυμαστόν. Related to θαυμάζω (to marvel).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Semeion emphasizes the significance of the miracle as pointing to something beyond itself. Teras emphasizes the wonder it evokes. Dynamis emphasizes the power displayed.

exampleVerse.greek: πολλὰ μὲν οὖν καὶ ἄλλα σημεῖα ἐποίησεν ὁ Ἰησοῦς... ταῦτα δὲ γέγραπται ἵνα πιστεύ[σ]ητε
exampleVerse.english: Jesus did many other signs (sēmeion)... but these are written so that you may believe

synonymGroups.practicalTip: John uses σημεῖα (signs) because miracles are meant to point beyond themselves to Christ. If we marvel at the power (δύναμις) but miss the significance (σημεῖον), we've missed the point.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Clothing and Garments
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek uses different words for clothing, from outer garments to undergarments to robes. These distinctions clarify passages about dress and the metaphorical 'putting on' of virtues.

words.nuance: An outer garment, cloak, robe. The general word for clothing, often the outer robe. Soldiers cast lots for Jesus' ἱμάτιον. Also used metaphorically for spiritual covering.
A tunic, the inner garment worn next to the skin. 'If someone takes your χιτών, give him your ἱμάτιον also' - offering both inner and outer garments.
A long robe, stately garment. Often worn by those of dignity or authority. The prodigal son received the 'best robe.' Scribes who love to walk in long robes.
Clothing, what is put on. From ἐνδύω (to put on). General term for apparel. 'Take no thought for... what you shall put on.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Himation is the outer garment, the cloak. Chitōn is the inner garment, the tunic. Together they represent complete clothing.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐνδύσασθε οὖν... σπλάγχνα οἰκτιρμοῦ
exampleVerse.english: Put on (endyō) then... compassionate hearts

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul says 'put on' (ἐνδύω) Christ or virtues, he uses clothing language. Just as we deliberately dress each morning, we deliberately clothe ourselves with Christ-like character.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Test and Temptation
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between testing with intent to prove (δοκιμάζω) and testing with intent to entice to sin (πειράζω). God tests but never tempts to evil.

words.nuance: To test, try, tempt. Can be neutral (testing to prove) or negative (tempting to sin). Satan 'tempts' to evil; God 'tests' to strengthen. Context determines which.
To test, examine, prove by testing. Always with the expectation of approval. Testing metals to prove their genuineness. 'Test everything; hold fast what is good.'
Trial, temptation, testing. The noun form of πειράζω. Can refer to trials that strengthen faith or temptations that entice to sin. 'Lead us not into temptation.'
Proof, test, approved character. The result of testing - proven character. 'Suffering produces endurance, and endurance produces proven character.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Peirazo may be used in a good sense, to try or test, and in a bad sense, to tempt, to solicit to sin. Dokimazo is always used in a good sense, to prove with a view to approval.

exampleVerse.greek: ὁ θεὸς ἀπείραστός ἐστιν κακῶν, πειράζει δὲ αὐτὸς οὐδένα
exampleVerse.english: God cannot be tempted (apeirastos) with evil, and he himself tempts (peirazō) no one

synonymGroups.practicalTip: James clarifies: God δοκιμάζω (tests to prove) but never πειράζω (tempts to sin). Trials strengthen; temptations entice. The same situation may be God's test and Satan's temptation.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Reward
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between wages earned (μισθός), recompense returned (ἀνταπόδομα), and gracious gifts (χάρισμα). These clarify the relationship between works, rewards, and grace.

words.nuance: Wages, hire, reward. Payment for work done. Used both for literal wages and for divine rewards. 'Great is your reward in heaven.' The laborer deserves his wages.
Recompense, the paying back of wages, reward or punishment. Can be positive or negative depending on what is deserved. God is a rewarder of those who seek Him.
Recompense, requital, what is paid back. From ἀντί (in return) + ἀποδίδωμι (pay). Something given in return for what was done.
The prize awarded to victors in games. Paul uses athletic imagery: 'Run in such a way as to get the prize.' The crown awaiting faithful runners.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Misthos denotes wages, the payment due for work done. It is used of the reward which God bestows, or will bestow, upon His servants.

exampleVerse.greek: οὕτως τρέχετε ἵνα καταλάβητε τὸ βραβεῖον
exampleVerse.english: Run in such a way that you may obtain the prize (brabeion)

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Salvation is a gift (χάρισμα), not μισθός (wages). But within salvation, faithful service receives μισθός (reward). We cannot earn salvation, but we can earn crowns.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Eternal/Everlasting
synonymGroups.introduction: English uses 'eternal' and 'everlasting' interchangeably, but Greek has distinct terms. This distinction is crucial for understanding 'eternal life,' 'eternal punishment,' and the nature of God's existence.

words.nuance: The primary NT word for 'eternal.' Derived from αἰών (age), it can mean 'belonging to the coming age' or 'age-long.' When applied to God or divine realities, it indicates timeless, unending existence. The word carries qualitative as well as quantitative meaning - not just endless duration but the quality of the age to come.

Rare in the NT (only twice), this word unambiguously means 'everlasting' in the sense of unending duration. It emphasizes continuous, unbroken existence without beginning or end. Used for God's eternal power (Rom 1:20) and the everlasting chains binding fallen angels (Jude 6).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Aidios is used of that which is endless in duration, while aiōnios may sometimes suggest that which is timeless in quality, belonging to the eternal order of things.

exampleVerse.greek: ἥ τε ἀΐδιος αὐτοῦ δύναμις καὶ θειότης
exampleVerse.english: His eternal (aidios) power and divine nature.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When you see 'eternal life' (ζωὴ αἰώνιος), remember it means not just life without end but life of a different quality - the life of the coming age, experienced now through Christ. The term points to both duration and character.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Covenant/Testament
synonymGroups.introduction: The Greek word for 'covenant' in the NT (διαθήκη) differs from the classical word for mutual agreements (συνθήκη). This choice reveals something profound about the nature of God's relationship with His people - it is not a negotiated contract but a gracious disposition.

words.nuance: The NT word for God's covenant. Unlike συνθήκη (mutual agreement), διαθήκη emphasizes a unilateral disposition - like a will or testament that one party establishes. God initiates and guarantees His covenant; humans receive it. The LXX translators chose this word (not συνθήκη) to translate Hebrew בְּרִית (berith).

Classical Greek word for a mutual agreement or treaty between equal parties. Significantly, the NT never uses this word for God's covenant. God does not negotiate terms with humanity; He graciously establishes His covenant. This word does not appear in the NT at all.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Diathēkē primarily signifies a disposition of property by will or otherwise. In its use in the Septuagint it is the rendering of a Hebrew word meaning a 'covenant' or agreement. The choice of this word by the LXX, instead of synthēkē, is significant: God's covenant is not a mutual compact but a sovereign disposition.

exampleVerse.greek: διαθήκης καινῆς μεσίτης ἐστίν
exampleVerse.english: He is the mediator of a new covenant (diathēkē).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When studying the 'new covenant' passages (Jer 31, Heb 8-10), remember that διαθήκη emphasizes God's gracious initiative. The covenant is His promise, guaranteed by His character, not a bargain we negotiate with Him.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Obey/Submit
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for obedience, each with distinct emphases. Some stress listening and responding, others emphasize persuasion and trust, and still others focus on orderly submission. Understanding these helps clarify NT commands about obedience.

words.nuance: Literally 'to hear under' - to listen carefully and respond accordingly. Emphasizes hearing and heeding, the obedience that comes from careful attention to what is commanded. Used for obeying parents (Eph 6:1), masters (Eph 6:5), and the gospel (Rom 10:16).

In its middle/passive forms, means 'to be persuaded, to trust, to obey.' The obedience that flows from inner conviction rather than external compulsion. Used for obeying leaders (Heb 13:17) - suggesting willing, convinced submission rather than mere compliance.

A military term meaning to arrange under, to subordinate. Emphasizes taking one's proper place in an ordered structure. Used for wives to husbands (Eph 5:22), church to Christ (Eph 5:24), citizens to government (Rom 13:1). Often middle voice: 'to voluntarily place oneself under.'
Combines πείθω (persuade/obey) with ἀρχή (authority). Emphasizes obedience to constituted authority. Used in Acts 5:29 'We must obey God rather than men' - obedience to legitimate authority.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Hypakouō stresses the idea of hearing and responding; peithō suggests the obedience that springs from persuasion or trust; hupotassō implies the orderly arrangement of subordination.

exampleVerse.greek: πείθεσθε τοῖς ἡγουμένοις ὑμῶν καὶ ὑπείκετε
exampleVerse.english: Obey (peithō - be persuaded by) your leaders and submit.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Note that biblical obedience is never mindless compliance. ὑπακούω involves careful listening; πείθω involves conviction; ὑποτάσσω often appears in middle voice, suggesting voluntary placement. Christian obedience is intelligent, willing, and ordered.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Patience/Endurance
synonymGroups.introduction: English 'patience' covers two distinct Greek concepts: patience with people (μακροθυμία) and endurance under circumstances (ὑπομονή). Confusing them weakens our understanding of key NT virtues.

words.nuance: Literally 'long-tempered' - the opposite of quick-tempered. Patience with people who provoke, offend, or wrong us. It is not retaliating or giving up on difficult people. A fruit of the Spirit (Gal 5:22) and an attribute of God who is 'slow to anger' toward sinners.

Literally 'remaining under' - standing firm under pressure, trial, or difficulty. Not passive resignation but active, courageous endurance. The fortitude that perseveres through suffering while maintaining faith and hope. The mark of tested faith (Jas 1:3-4).

A holding back, restraint, forbearance. Used of God's patience in withholding judgment (Rom 2:4; 3:26). While μακροθυμία emphasizes long-suffering disposition, ἀνοχή emphasizes the restraint of deserved punishment.
