synonymGroups.vineQuote: Makrothumia is the quality that does not easily give up in the face of provocation by people; hupomonē is the temper that does not surrender to circumstances or succumb under trial.

exampleVerse.greek: εἰς πᾶσαν ὑπομονὴν καὶ μακροθυμίαν μετὰ χαρᾶς
exampleVerse.english: For all endurance (hypomonē) and patience (makrothymia) with joy.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When praying for 'patience,' be specific: Do you need μακροθυμία (patience with a difficult person) or ὑπομονή (endurance through a hard circumstance)? The distinction helps target both prayer and practice.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Comfort/Encourage
synonymGroups.introduction: The NT uses several words for comfort and encouragement. The most significant is παρακαλέω (the root of 'Paraclete,' Jesus' name for the Holy Spirit). Understanding these words enriches our grasp of Christian consolation and the Spirit's ministry.

words.shortDef: to call alongside, encourage, exhort, comfort
words.nuance: The richest NT word for encouragement. Literally 'to call alongside.' The range of meaning includes: exhorting (urging to action), comforting (consoling in sorrow), encouraging (strengthening resolve), and entreating (making request). Context determines emphasis. The Holy Spirit is the Paráklētos (Παράκλητος) - the One called alongside to help.

A tender word for consolation, especially in grief or sorrow. While παρακαλέω can include urging to action, παραμυθέομαι emphasizes gentle, sympathetic comfort. Used for comforting the bereaved (John 11:19, 31) and tender care (1 Thess 2:11; 5:14).
A soothing, cheering word. Only in Col 3:11 in the NT. The root of English 'paregoric' (a soothing medicine). Emphasizes the comforting, reassuring aspect rather than exhortation.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Parakaleō primarily means 'to call to one's side,' hence to comfort, exhort, entreat. Paramytheomai suggests tender comfort, especially in sorrow, a comforting that is more personal and sympathetic.

exampleVerse.greek: ὁ θεὸς πάσης παρακλήσεως, ὁ παρακαλῶν ἡμᾶς
exampleVerse.english: The God of all comfort (paraklēsis), who comforts (parakaleō) us.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The Holy Spirit as 'Paraclete' (John 14-16) means far more than 'Comforter.' He is the One called alongside to encourage, strengthen, convict, guide, and advocate. Every meaning of παρακαλέω applies to His ministry.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Good
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for 'good,' each with distinct emphasis. Some stress inherent quality, others beauty and excellence, still others usefulness or kindness. These distinctions illuminate NT descriptions of God, people, and actions.

words.nuance: Moral goodness that benefits others. Emphasizes intrinsic goodness and its beneficial effect. Used of God (Matt 19:17 'One is good'), good works (Eph 2:10), and the good fruit produced by believers. Often paired with καλός but emphasizes the beneficial aspect more strongly.

Good in the sense of beautiful, noble, or excellent. Emphasizes quality, attractiveness, and fitness for purpose. Used for 'good works' that are visible and praiseworthy (Matt 5:16), 'good' soil (Mark 4:8), the 'good shepherd' (John 10:11). The aesthetic and ethical merge.

Good in the sense of kind, pleasant, or serviceable. Emphasizes usefulness and kindness in dealings with others. Used of God's kindness (Rom 2:4; Eph 2:7), the 'easy' yoke of Christ (Matt 11:30), and gracious speech (Eph 4:32).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Agathos describes that which, being good in its character or constitution, is beneficial in its effect; kalos denotes that which is intrinsically good, beautiful, or honorable; chrestos suggests what is suitable, serviceable, and kind.

exampleVerse.greek: εἷς ἐστιν ὁ ἀγαθός
exampleVerse.english: There is only One who is good (agathos).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Scripture says 'do good,' note which word is used: ἀγαθός emphasizes beneficial effect on others; καλός emphasizes visible excellence that glorifies God. Both are called for (Gal 6:10; Titus 3:8).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Evil/Bad
synonymGroups.introduction: As Greek distinguishes types of good, it also distinguishes types of evil. Some words emphasize harmful quality, others active malice, still others worthlessness. The 'evil one' (πονηρός) and his works are described with precision.

words.nuance: The general word for evil or bad, emphasizing harmful quality or effect. Can refer to moral evil (Rom 12:17) or physical harm (Acts 28:5). Often contrasted with ἀγαθός. The corresponding noun κακία means 'malice' or 'wickedness.'

Evil in an active, malignant sense - not merely bad but actively harmful and corrupting. The word used for 'the evil one' (ὁ πονηρός, Matt 13:19; 1 John 5:19). Implies a malevolent influence that spreads corruption. Used for evil eyes (Matt 6:23), evil generations (Matt 12:39), and evil hearts (Heb 3:12).

Evil in the sense of worthless, trivial, or contemptible. Not so much actively malignant as base and good-for-nothing. Used for evil deeds that merit judgment (John 5:29; Rom 9:11; 2 Cor 5:10). Emphasizes the worthlessness of sin.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Kakos stands for 'bad' in character, poneros denotes what is actively evil in influence, phaulos suggests what is worthless or contemptible.

exampleVerse.greek: ῥῦσαι ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ τοῦ πονηροῦ
exampleVerse.english: Deliver us from the evil one (ponēros).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When the NT speaks of 'the evil one' (ὁ πονηρός), the word choice emphasizes Satan's actively malignant influence. He is not merely 'bad' (κακός) but aggressively corrupting and destructive.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Death and Life
synonymGroups.introduction: The contrast between death and life runs through all Scripture. Greek provides distinct words that reveal different aspects: physical death vs. spiritual death, biological life vs. eternal life, natural life vs. soul. These distinctions are foundational for NT theology.

words.nuance: Death as state or power. Used for physical death (Phil 1:20), spiritual death (separation from God, Rom 6:23), and 'the second death' (Rev 20:14). Death is personified as an enemy (1 Cor 15:26) and as having lost its sting through Christ (1 Cor 15:55).

Life in its highest sense - the life that God has in Himself and gives to believers. The word for 'eternal life' (ζωὴ αἰώνιος). Not merely biological existence but spiritual vitality, abundant life (John 10:10), the life that is in Christ (John 1:4; 14:6). The opposite of spiritual death.

Life in terms of its duration, manner of living, or means of subsistence. Used for livelihood/possessions (Mark 12:44; Luke 8:14), the duration of life (1 Pet 4:3), and lifestyle (1 Tim 2:2). The root of 'biology.' Distinguished from ζωή as the outward life is from the inner life principle.

The soul or self - the seat of personality, emotions, and natural life. Can mean physical life (Matt 6:25), the soul as distinct from body (Matt 10:28), or the whole person (Acts 2:41 'three thousand souls'). Distinguished from πνεῦμα (spirit) as the self-conscious life is from the God-conscious spirit.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Zōē is used of life as the absolute gift of God in Christ, βίος of the period or manner of life, ψυχή of the natural life in relation to the soul and self.

exampleVerse.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ἀνάστασις καὶ ἡ ζωή
exampleVerse.english: I am the resurrection and the life (zōē).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Jesus offers 'life' (ζωή), He offers the very life of God - not just a longer βίος or a better ψυχή, but divine, eternal, abundant ζωή. This is the life we lost in Adam and receive in Christ.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Witness/Testimony
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several related words for witness and testimony. Understanding their distinctions helps grasp the NT emphasis on eyewitness testimony, the church's mission to testify, and ultimately, martyrdom - witness unto death.

words.nuance: The person who bears witness - one who has firsthand knowledge and testifies to what they have seen or known. The apostles were 'witnesses' to the resurrection (Acts 1:8, 22). Later developed into 'martyr' - one who witnesses to Christ even unto death (Acts 22:20; Rev 2:13).

The testimony itself - the content of what is witnessed or the act of witnessing. John's Gospel emphasizes Jesus' 'testimony' and God's testimony about the Son (John 1:7; 5:31-36; 1 John 5:9-11). The testimony establishes truth.

Testimony as proof or evidence - often with the sense of testimony that serves as evidence against or for someone. Used for the gospel witness 'as a testimony to all nations' (Matt 24:14). Also refers to the 'tabernacle of testimony' (Acts 7:44).

The verb form - to give testimony, to bear witness. Especially prominent in John's Gospel: John the Baptist 'came to bear witness' (John 1:7-8); Jesus bears witness to what He has seen (John 3:11, 32); the Spirit will 'bear witness' (John 15:26).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Martys denotes one who can or does give evidence concerning facts; martyria is the testimony given; martyrion is testimony with special reference to its evidential value.

exampleVerse.greek: ἔσεσθέ μου μάρτυρες ἔν τε Ἰερουσαλὴμ... καὶ ἕως ἐσχάτου τῆς γῆς
exampleVerse.english: You will be my witnesses in Jerusalem... to the ends of the earth.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The connection between 'witness' and 'martyr' is not accidental. Early Christians understood that bearing faithful witness might require dying for that testimony. When you see 'witness' in the NT, consider: What has this person seen? What are they willing to stake on it?

synonymGroups.title: Words for Servant/Slave
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes different types of service. Some emphasize bondage to a master, others table service, others official assistance, still others sacred ministry. These distinctions illuminate NT teaching on Christian service and ministry roles.

words.nuance: The most complete form of servitude - one who belongs entirely to another. Not merely hired but owned. Paul calls himself 'slave of Christ' (Rom 1:1; Phil 1:1). Believers are 'slaves of righteousness' (Rom 6:18) or 'slaves of sin' (Rom 6:17). Emphasizes total belonging and obedience.

Originally one who serves at table, then more broadly any servant or minister. Less emphasis on bondage, more on active service. Used for church office 'deacon' (Phil 1:1; 1 Tim 3:8). Christ came 'not to be served but to serve' (διακονῆσαι, Mark 10:45). The root of 'deacon' and 'diaconate.'

Literally an 'under-rower' (one rowing in a ship's lower tier), hence one who serves under another's direction. An attendant who carries out orders. Used for synagogue attendant (Luke 4:20), officers of the court (Matt 26:58), and ministers of the word (Luke 1:2; Acts 26:16).

One who performs public service, especially religious service. Used for priests (Heb 8:2), angels (Heb 1:7), governmental authorities (Rom 13:6), and Paul's ministry (Rom 15:16). The root of 'liturgy.' Emphasizes official, often sacred, service.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Doulos is one whose will is swallowed up in the will of another; diakonos is one who renders service; hypēretēs is one who acts under direction; leitourgos performs sacred or public duty.

exampleVerse.greek: ὃς ἂν θέλῃ μέγας γενέσθαι ἐν ὑμῖν ἔσται ὑμῶν διάκονος, καὶ ὃς ἂν θέλῃ ἐν ὑμῖν εἶναι πρῶτος ἔσται πάντων δοῦλος
exampleVerse.english: Whoever wants to be great must be your servant (diakonos), and whoever wants to be first must be slave (doulos) of all.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul calls himself 'slave of Christ' (δοῦλος Χριστοῦ), he uses the strongest term - total belonging. When Scripture speaks of 'deacons' (διάκονοι), it emphasizes active service. Note which word is used to understand the type of service intended.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Power/Authority
synonymGroups.introduction: English 'power' covers several Greek concepts: inherent ability, delegated authority, physical strength, and sovereign might. These distinctions illuminate NT teaching about God's power, Christ's authority, and the power available to believers.

words.nuance: Inherent power or ability - the capacity to do something. The power resident in someone or something. Used for God's power (Rom 1:16, 20), the power of Christ's resurrection (Phil 3:10), miracles ('powers,' Matt 11:20), and the power the Spirit gives believers (Acts 1:8). Root of 'dynamite' and 'dynamic.'

The right or authority to do something - often delegated. Jesus taught with authority (Matt 7:29), gave disciples authority over demons (Luke 9:1), and declared 'all authority in heaven and earth is given to me' (Matt 28:18). Used for governmental authorities (Rom 13:1-3). Emphasizes legitimate right, not just ability.
Strength as possessed, especially physical strength or forceful might. 'Love the Lord with all your strength' (Mark 12:30). God's 'mighty strength' (Eph 1:19; 6:10). The strength exerted in action.

Sovereign might, ruling power, dominion. Used almost exclusively of God in NT: 'the might of His glory' (Col 1:11), 'to Him be... dominion forever' (1 Pet 5:11; Jude 25). Emphasizes supreme, conquering power. Root of '-cracy' words (democracy, theocracy).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Dynamis is ability or capability; exousia is the right to exercise power; ischys is strength as an endowment; kratos is the manifestation of power in ruling.

exampleVerse.greek: τὸ ὑπερβάλλον μέγεθος τῆς δυνάμεως αὐτοῦ... κατὰ τὴν ἐνέργειαν τοῦ κράτους τῆς ἰσχύος αὐτοῦ... ὑπεράνω πάσης... ἐξουσίας
exampleVerse.english: The surpassing greatness of His power (dynamis)... according to the working of His mighty (kratos) strength (ischys)... far above all... authority (exousia).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When promised 'power' (δύναμις) in Acts 1:8, it's enabling ability from the Spirit. When Jesus claims 'authority' (ἐξουσία) in Matt 28:18, it's rightful rule. Distinguish: Are you lacking ability (δύναμις) or authority (ἐξουσία)? God supplies both.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Temple/Sanctuary
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes the temple complex as a whole from the sanctuary proper. This distinction is crucial for understanding 'your body is a temple' - which word is used? - and for grasping the significance of the veil being torn.

words.nuance: The whole temple area including all the courts - the Court of Gentiles, Court of Women, etc. The public, accessible areas where teaching occurred. Jesus 'cleansed the temple' (ἱερόν, Matt 21:12) and taught in the temple (Matt 26:55). This is where people gathered.

The sanctuary proper - the sacred inner structure containing the Holy Place and Most Holy Place. Where God dwells. Only priests entered the Holy Place; only the high priest entered the Most Holy Place once yearly. Zechariah served in the ναός (Luke 1:9). The veil of the ναός was torn (Matt 27:51). Believers are the ναός of the Holy Spirit (1 Cor 3:16; 6:19).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Hieron denotes the entire building with its precincts, naos the inner sanctuary where God dwells. When Paul says the body is a temple (naos), he means God's dwelling-place, not merely a sacred precinct.

exampleVerse.greek: τὸ σῶμα ὑμῶν ναὸς τοῦ ἐν ὑμῖν ἁγίου πνεύματός ἐστιν
exampleVerse.english: Your body is a sanctuary (naos) of the Holy Spirit who is in you.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul says 'your body is a temple (ναός),' he uses the word for the sacred sanctuary - God's dwelling place. You are not merely part of a religious complex but the very dwelling of God's Spirit. This elevates the body's significance immensely.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Clean/Pure
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for cleanness and purity, each with distinct emphasis. Some stress ceremonial cleanness, others moral purity, still others sincerity or transparency. These illuminate NT teaching on holiness and integrity.

words.nuance: The general word for clean or pure - free from contamination, whether ritual or moral. 'Blessed are the pure in heart' (Matt 5:8). 'You are already clean because of the word' (John 15:3). Used for ceremonial cleanness (Luke 11:41) and moral purity. The root of 'catharsis.'

Moral purity especially in the sense of chastity and innocence - free from defilement. Related to ἅγιος (holy). Used for sexual purity (2 Cor 11:2; 1 Tim 5:22), pure motives (Phil 1:17), and the wisdom from above (Jas 3:17). Emphasizes moral innocence.

Pure in the sense of transparent, sincere, unmixed. Possibly from εἵλη (sunlight) + κρίνω (judge) - what stands the test of being examined in sunlight, revealing no flaws or mixture. Used for sincere faith (Phil 1:10) and pure minds (2 Pet 3:1). Emphasizes genuineness.

Negation of 'defiled' - that which has no stain or contamination. Used for the undefiled marriage bed (Heb 13:4), undefiled religion (Jas 1:27), and Christ as undefiled high priest (Heb 7:26). Emphasizes freedom from pollution.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Katharos is the general term for clean; hagnos emphasizes moral purity and chastity; eilikrinēs stresses sincerity and genuineness tested by light; amiantos denotes freedom from pollution or stain.

exampleVerse.greek: μακάριοι οἱ καθαροὶ τῇ καρδίᾳ, ὅτι αὐτοὶ τὸν θεὸν ὄψονται
exampleVerse.english: Blessed are the pure (katharos) in heart, for they will see God.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When examining your heart, consider: Is it καθαρός (clean from contamination)? Is it ἁγνός (morally innocent)? Is it εἰλικρινής (genuine when examined in light)? Each word probes a different aspect of purity.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Child/Son
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between children by birth relationship, children by legal status, and children by age. These distinctions illuminate NT teaching on believers as God's children - both born of Him and adopted as sons with full inheritance rights.

words.nuance: Child in terms of origin and relationship - one born of a parent. Emphasizes the birth relationship. 'Children of God' (τέκνα θεοῦ, John 1:12) stresses being born of God, having His nature. Used for natural children and metaphorically for spiritual offspring.

Son in terms of status, rights, and inheritance - the legal position. Emphasizes privilege and heirship. 'Sons of God' (υἱοὶ θεοῦ, Rom 8:14) stresses the full legal standing and inheritance rights. Used for 'Son of Man,' 'Son of God,' and believers as adopted sons.

A young child, emphasizing age and immaturity. Used for infants and small children (Matt 2:8 - 'the child' Jesus). Also used affectionately for disciples (John 21:5 - 'Children, have you any fish?'). Diminutive form emphasizing youth.

An infant or one who cannot speak (νη- 'not' + ἔπος 'word'). Emphasizes immaturity and need for growth. Used negatively for spiritual immaturity (1 Cor 3:1; Heb 5:13) and positively for childlike receptivity (Matt 11:25). Contrasted with mature (τέλειος).

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Teknon emphasizes the fact of birth; huios emphasizes dignity and character of relationship; paidion stresses age and immaturity; nēpios suggests one unable to speak, hence an infant or immature one.

exampleVerse.greek: ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς ἐξουσίαν τέκνα θεοῦ γενέσθαι
exampleVerse.english: He gave them the right to become children (tekna) of God.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Scripture calls believers 'children' (τέκνα) of God, it emphasizes new birth - we share God's nature. When it calls us 'sons' (υἱοί), it emphasizes legal status - we have full inheritance rights. Both are true: born of God AND adopted as heirs.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Age/World
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between 'age' (a period of time, an era) and 'world' (the created order or human society). This distinction is crucial for understanding 'this age' versus 'the age to come' and the believer's relationship to 'the world.'

words.nuance: A period of time, an age or era. 'This age' (ὁ αἰὼν οὗτος) is the present evil age under Satan's influence. 'The age to come' (ὁ αἰὼν μέλλων) is the messianic age of salvation. Can mean 'forever' (εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα) or 'eternity.' The root of 'eon.' Emphasizes time dimension.

The ordered world, universe, or human society. Has multiple senses: (1) the created universe (John 1:10a); (2) humanity (John 3:16 - God loved the world); (3) the world-system opposed to God (1 John 2:15 - do not love the world). Emphasizes space/order dimension.

The inhabited earth, often the Roman world specifically. 'A decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the world (οἰκουμένη) should be registered' (Luke 2:1). 'This gospel will be proclaimed throughout the whole world (οἰκουμένη)' (Matt 24:14). The civilized, inhabited world.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Aiōn denotes a period of time marked by spiritual or moral characteristics; kosmos represents the ordered system, whether physical creation or human society organized apart from God; oikoumenē is the inhabited earth.

exampleVerse.greek: μὴ συσχηματίζεσθε τῷ αἰῶνι τούτῳ
exampleVerse.english: Do not be conformed to this age (aiōn).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Jesus says the 'world' (κόσμος) hates believers (John 15:18-19), He means human society organized against God. When Paul says not to be conformed to 'this age' (αἰών), he means the present era's values. The enemy operates through both - the world-system AND the present evil age.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Teach/Learn
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has distinct words for teaching, learning, and training. Some emphasize instruction, others the learner's appropriation, still others discipline and correction. These illuminate NT discipleship - becoming a μαθητής (disciple/learner) of Jesus.

words.nuance: To teach, give instruction - the activity of the teacher imparting knowledge or skill. Jesus taught (ἐδίδασκεν) in synagogues and temple. The apostles devoted themselves to teaching (Acts 2:42). Emphasizes the systematic communication of truth. Root of 'didactic.'

To learn, acquire knowledge - the activity of the student receiving instruction. 'Learn from me' (Matt 11:29). The μαθητής (disciple) is literally 'a learner.' Emphasizes the student's appropriation of what is taught. Learning through experience and practice, not just hearing.

To train a child (παῖς), hence to educate, discipline, or correct. Includes instruction but emphasizes formation of character through discipline. God 'disciplines' (παιδεύει) those He loves (Heb 12:6). Paul was 'educated' (πεπαιδευμένος) under Gamaliel (Acts 22:3). Root of 'pedagogy.'

To instruct orally, to teach by word of mouth. Theophilus was 'instructed' (κατηχήθης, Luke 1:4). Apollos was 'instructed' in the way of the Lord (Acts 18:25). The root of 'catechism' - systematic oral instruction in the faith.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Didaskō is to teach, hold discourse with others to instruct them; manthanō is to learn, increase one's knowledge by instruction or experience; paideuō is to train children, including discipline and correction; katēcheō is to sound down into the ears, to instruct orally.

exampleVerse.greek: μάθετε ἀπ᾽ ἐμοῦ, ὅτι πραΰς εἰμι
exampleVerse.english: Learn (manthanō) from me, for I am gentle.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Being a 'disciple' (μαθητής) means being a learner - one who not only hears teaching (διδασκαλία) but learns it (μανθάνω). God also disciplines (παιδεύω) us as children. Christian formation involves all three: instruction, learning, and formative discipline.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Rise/Raise
synonymGroups.introduction: Two main Greek verbs describe resurrection: ἀνίστημι (to stand up, rise) and ἐγείρω (to wake, rouse, raise). Both are used for Christ's resurrection and believers' future resurrection, sometimes interchangeably, but with subtle differences in emphasis.

words.shortDef: to rise, stand up, raise up
words.nuance: To cause to rise or to rise oneself - standing up from sitting, lying, or death. The intransitive use emphasizes the subject's own action of rising. 'He rose' (ἀνέστη, Mark 8:31; 9:31; 10:34). The noun ἀνάστασις (resurrection) comes from this verb. Emphasizes the rising action.

To wake from sleep, to rouse, to raise up. Often passive for resurrection: 'He was raised' (ἠγέρθη, 1 Cor 15:4) - emphasizing God's action in raising Jesus. 'God raised Him from the dead' (Acts 3:15). The passive voice highlights divine action, the Father raising the Son.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Anistēmi signifies to cause to stand up or to stand up oneself; egeirō means to rouse from sleep or death. In resurrection contexts, anistēmi often stresses the rising, egeirō the rousing by another (God the Father).

exampleVerse.greek: καὶ ὅτι ἐγήγερται τῇ ἡμέρᾳ τῇ τρίτῃ κατὰ τὰς γραφάς
exampleVerse.english: And that He was raised (egeirō - passive) on the third day according to the Scriptures.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Paul says Christ 'was raised' (ἠγέρθη, passive), he emphasizes the Father's action in raising the Son. When Mark says 'He will rise' (ἀναστήσεται), the focus is on Christ's own rising. Both are true: the Father raised Him, and He rose. The resurrection is Trinitarian.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Will/Desire
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has two main verbs for willing or wishing. Understanding their distinction helps interpret passages about God's will, human desires, and the interplay between divine sovereignty and human responsibility.

words.nuance: To will, wish, or desire - often emphasizing inclination, impulse, or emotional desire. Can express strong personal desire ('I want') or deliberate choice. 'What do you want (θέλεις) me to do for you?' (Mark 10:51). 'God wills (θέλει) all people to be saved' (1 Tim 2:4). The more common word for willing.

To will with deliberation, to purpose, to plan. Emphasizes reasoned, deliberate intention more than emotional desire. Often used for God's sovereign counsel: 'the purpose (βουλή) of His will' (Eph 1:11). 'The Lord's will (βούλημα) be done' (Acts 21:14). Suggests settled purpose.

words.shortDef: to desire earnestly, long for, lust
words.nuance: To set one's heart upon, to desire intensely. Can be positive ('I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover,' Luke 22:15) or negative ('do not covet,' Rom 7:7; 'the lust of the flesh,' Gal 5:16). Stronger emotional intensity than θέλω. Emphasizes passionate desire.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Thelō expresses the will that proceeds from inclination; boulomai expresses the will that proceeds from deliberation and purpose; epithymeō denotes a strong desire directed toward something, whether good or evil.

exampleVerse.greek: κατὰ τὴν βουλὴν τοῦ θελήματος αὐτοῦ
exampleVerse.english: According to the counsel (boulē) of His will (thelēma).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Scripture speaks of God's 'will' (θέλημα), it often means His revealed desire - what pleases Him. When it speaks of His 'purpose' (βουλή), it often means His sovereign plan that cannot be thwarted. Both are true: God desires all to be saved (θέλει, 1 Tim 2:4), and His purposes (βουλή) always stand (Isa 46:10).

synonymGroups.title: Words for Heal/Cure
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has several words for healing, each with distinct emphasis. Some stress the process of treatment, others the instantaneous cure, and one connects physical healing to spiritual salvation. These distinctions illuminate the Gospel healing narratives.

words.shortDef: to heal, cure, serve, treat (process of care)
words.nuance: To heal by treating, serving, or caring for - emphasizing the process of treatment and restoration. Originally meant 'to serve' or 'attend to.' Used for Jesus healing diseases (Matt 4:23-24; 12:15). The root of 'therapy' and 'therapeutic.' Suggests ongoing care and treatment.

To heal or cure - often emphasizing instantaneous, complete healing. The physician's term for effecting a cure. 'Your faith has healed (ἰάσατο) you' (Luke 17:19). 'By His wounds you have been healed (ἰάθητε)' (1 Pet 2:24). Can refer to physical or spiritual healing.

words.shortDef: to save, heal, deliver, make whole
words.nuance: To save, rescue, deliver - used for both spiritual salvation and physical healing. 'Your faith has saved/healed (σέσωκεν) you' (Mark 5:34; 10:52; Luke 7:50; 17:19). The overlap between 'heal' and 'save' shows the holistic nature of Jesus' ministry. Physical healing points to greater salvation.

To be healthy, sound, or whole - the state of health rather than the act of healing. 'Those who are well (ὑγιαίνοντες) have no need of a physician' (Luke 5:31). Used metaphorically for 'sound doctrine' (1 Tim 1:10; 2 Tim 4:3; Titus 1:9). The root of 'hygiene.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Therapeuō emphasizes the process of healing and care; iaomai stresses the accomplished cure; sōzō connects physical healing to the broader concept of salvation and deliverance; hygiainō describes the resultant state of health.

exampleVerse.greek: ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε· ὕπαγε εἰς εἰρήνην καὶ ἴσθι ὑγιὴς
exampleVerse.english: Your faith has saved/healed (sōzō) you; go in peace and be healed/whole (hygiēs).

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When Jesus says 'your faith has saved you' (σέσωκεν) to those He heals, the word deliberately connects physical healing to spiritual salvation. The healings are signs pointing to greater wholeness - the salvation Christ brings encompasses body and soul.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Walk/Conduct
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek uses several 'walking' words metaphorically for how one lives or conducts oneself. This is especially prominent in Paul's letters: believers are to 'walk' in newness of life, by the Spirit, in love. The metaphor emphasizes daily, step-by-step living.

words.nuance: Literally to walk around; metaphorically, to conduct one's life, to live in a certain manner. Paul's characteristic term for Christian living: 'walk in newness of life' (Rom 6:4), 'walk by the Spirit' (Gal 5:16), 'walk in love' (Eph 5:2), 'walk as children of light' (Eph 5:8). Emphasizes the ongoing pattern of daily life.

To go, travel, or journey - more directional than περιπατέω. Often literal (journeying from place to place) but also metaphorical for pursuing a course of life: 'go in peace' (Luke 7:50), 'go and sin no more' (John 8:11). Emphasizes direction and destination.

words.shortDef: to walk in line, follow, conform to
words.nuance: To walk in line, to keep in step - a military term for marching in formation. 'If we live by the Spirit, let us also keep in step (στοιχῶμεν) with the Spirit' (Gal 5:25). 'Walk by the same rule' (Phil 3:16). Emphasizes orderly following and conformity to a standard.
To travel on a road (ὁδός). Less common, emphasizing the road or path being traveled. 'As they were journeying' (Luke 10:38). Related to ὁδός (way/road) - Christ is 'the Way.'

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Peripateō signifies one's habitual conduct or manner of life; poreuomai emphasizes the direction of one's going; stoicheō suggests walking in line, keeping step with a standard or rule.

exampleVerse.greek: πνεύματι περιπατεῖτε... εἰ ζῶμεν πνεύματι, πνεύματι καὶ στοιχῶμεν
exampleVerse.english: Walk (peripateō) by the Spirit... if we live by the Spirit, let us also keep in step (stoicheō) with the Spirit.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: Paul uses περιπατέω for the general lifestyle ('walk by the Spirit') and στοιχέω for the disciplined following ('keep in step'). Both are needed: general direction (περιπατέω) and moment-by-moment obedience (στοιχέω). The Christian life is a journey walked daily in step with the Spirit.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Bless/Blessed
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek has two main words translated 'bless' or 'blessed,' but they have distinct meanings. One involves speaking well (blessing), the other describes a state of happiness or favor (beatitude). The Beatitudes use one; doxologies use the other.

words.shortDef: to bless, speak well of, praise
words.nuance: To speak well of, to bless - either God blessing humans (conferring favor) or humans blessing God (praising). 'Blessed (εὐλογημένος) is He who comes in the name of the Lord' (Matt 21:9). 'Blessed be the God and Father' (Eph 1:3). Used at the Last Supper: Jesus 'blessed' the bread (Matt 26:26). Root of 'eulogy.'

To pronounce or consider someone blessed/happy - declaring their fortunate state. 'All generations will call me blessed (μακαριοῦσιν)' (Luke 1:48). 'We count them blessed (μακαρίζομεν) who remained steadfast' (Jas 5:11). Less about conferring blessing than recognizing it.

The adjective: blessed, happy, fortunate - describing a state of blessedness. The Beatitudes: 'Blessed (μακάριοι) are the poor in spirit' (Matt 5:3-11). 'Blessed is the man who...' (Ps 1:1 LXX; Rom 4:7-8). Describes the enviable condition of those favored by God.

The adjective from εὐλογέω - blessed or praised. Used almost exclusively of God: 'Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ' (Eph 1:3; 1 Pet 1:3). 'The blessed (εὐλογητός) God' (1 Tim 6:15). Describes God as worthy of blessing/praise.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Eulogeō means to speak well of, to bless; makarios describes a state of blessedness or happiness. When we bless God (εὐλογοῦμεν), we praise Him; when God blesses us (εὐλογεῖ), He bestows favor. The Beatitudes declare people μακάριοι - in an enviable state of divine favor.

exampleVerse.greek: μακάριοι οἱ πτωχοὶ τῷ πνεύματι
exampleVerse.english: Blessed (makarioi) are the poor in spirit.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: The Beatitudes use μακάριος (a state of blessedness) not εὐλογημένος (blessed by speech). Jesus declares certain people to be in an enviable state - already blessed by God - not that He is blessing them at that moment. The difference: εὐλογέω is the act of blessing; μακάριος is the resulting state.

synonymGroups.title: Words for Weep/Mourn/Lament
synonymGroups.introduction: Greek distinguishes between different types of sorrow and its expressions. Some words emphasize tears, others mourning rituals, still others vocal lamentation. These distinctions illuminate Gospel accounts of grief and the 'blessed' who mourn.

words.nuance: To weep, cry audibly - expressing grief through tears. 'Jesus wept (ἐδάκρυσεν)' uses a different word, but κλαίω is more common: 'weep with those who weep' (Rom 12:15), Peter 'wept bitterly' (Matt 26:75), the widow of Nain was weeping (Luke 7:13). Audible, emotional weeping.

To mourn, grieve - often the formal mourning for the dead or deep grief. 'Blessed are those who mourn (πενθοῦντες)' (Matt 5:4). 'You will weep and mourn (πενθήσετε)' (John 16:20). Can include mourning rituals and outward expressions of grief.

words.shortDef: to lament, wail, sing a dirge
words.nuance: To lament, wail, sing a funeral song - vocal, even musical lamentation. 'We played the flute for you and you did not dance; we sang a dirge (ἐθρηνήσαμεν) and you did not mourn' (Matt 11:17). Professional mourners would thrēneō at funerals. Loud, vocal grief.
To weep or shed tears - used only once: 'Jesus wept (ἐδάκρυσεν)' (John 11:35). Distinct from κλαίω in being quieter, less demonstrative. Jesus shed tears rather than wailing aloud. Deep, quiet grief.

synonymGroups.vineQuote: Klaiō signifies audible weeping; pentheō is mourning, especially formal or ritual mourning for the dead; thrēneō is vocal lamentation, singing a dirge; dakryō is simply to shed tears, used of Jesus at Lazarus's tomb.

exampleVerse.greek: μακάριοι οἱ πενθοῦντες, ὅτι αὐτοὶ παρακληθήσονται
exampleVerse.english: Blessed are those who mourn (pentheō), for they shall be comforted.

synonymGroups.practicalTip: When 'Jesus wept' (John 11:35) uses δακρύω rather than κλαίω, it suggests quiet tears rather than loud wailing - deeply moved yet composed. The Beatitude uses πενθέω - not just sadness but the grief that leads to God for comfort. Those who mourn over sin and suffering are blessed because they will receive divine comfort.
